plist.p: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the webcast for the presentation of the BBVA earnings for the first quarter of 2012. The presentation will be given by Ángel Cano, our Chief Operating Officer. And then, for the Q&A, which will take place immediately after the presentation, we'll also have with us Manuel González Cid, our Chief Financial Officer. Any questions can't be dealt with in the webcast due to lack of time will be answered by our Investor Relations team during the rest of the day.

Good morning, everyone, and welcome to this presentation of the BBVA Group earnings for first quarter of 2012. This quarter, as has been said in previous occasions, has shown uneven growth in the environment in which we operate. Thus for, we've got Europe. And although there's been clear-cut progress, especially in fiscal matters, we still have to recognize that there are different fronts where there are still problems, like Greece, despite the bailout plan – the second bailout plan and the restructuring of the debt, there are still problems, and contagion must be avoided to protect more solvent countries.

The second issue is governance in Europe. Here, we have to speed up the movement towards a monetary and fiscal union in Europe in order to recover confidence and to stabilize the different economies and avoid future crises. Then finally, in this very complex recessive environment in Europe, it's vital to roll out adjustment plans in order to correct some of the imbalances, and also to boost competitiveness and get back on the road to growth.

With this uneven scenario, we see differences in Europe. The peripheral countries were especially badly hit by the recession, including Spain, which is the focus of a lot of attention. I know that it's true that Spain is seeing big challenges, fiscal consolidation, debt and such. Nonetheless, its finance industry does have some sound fundamentals and the data are sometimes better than the average for Europe.

And as I said before, if we look elsewhere in the world, there's a quite different performance. Asia, South America, Mexico, they're all showing very sound growth and dynamic growth in their economies and, of course, the United States, where recovery is being consolidated progressively.

As I said, there's a lot of attention being focused on Spain, and so maybe we should shed some light on four fundamental concerns that people tend to have about Spain and see what's being done with each of them. First of all, fiscal consolidation. It is true that in Spain the main focus is on the structural deficit to get adjustment into the budget, and there are various initiatives that are being taken. And with respect to the national budget, the Budgetary Stability Act, and then the plans for rebalancing the regional governments' budgets and also a program for paying suppliers. In very little time, a lot of reforms have been adopted, but they're very deep reforms and there's still room for further measures to be taken. And I think that as the economy develops here in Spain, we will see new measures being taken.

The other issue in Spain is level of debt. Here, we should separate out the public debt from the private debt. When we are talking about public debt, in Spain last year it was about 69%. And that compares very well against the European average, which was 88% to GDP. And it's below the French level or the German level.

In the private sector, we should distinguish between households and companies. If we look at what's been happening in households, it's true that at the beginning of the crisis, they had borrowing requirements of about 2.7% of GDP. But at this stage in 2011, they have a net capacity that generates savings, which is now positive 2.3% to GDP.

However, in companies, the picture is a bit different. If we take out real estate developers, leverage is about 50% on average, whilst in the European Union, it would be more like 53%. So in terms of the debt level, we could say that it's already sustainable. And in the real estate sector, although it is a cause for concern, there's very sharp deleverage and an overhaul of its structure. As I was saying, this is a sustainable debt level then and not too far from the kind of levels we see elsewhere in Europe.

The third point of concern is the financial sector. Since 2007, a lot of progress has been made. You may remember that we had 45 savings banks at that time, whereas at the end of 2011, there were just 11. And we can expect that there will probably be about 6 by the end of this year. And over the last few quarters, we've seen that the process of closing down the number of branches has speeded up, with the closing of many branches. The main focus has been the last few quarters, and we can expect to see more closures over the next few months.

Moreover, there's a new Royal Legislative Decree that came into force on the 15 of April, which will mean that a lot of provisioning will have to be set aside for the banking industry in Spain, which will lead to further restructuring throughout the country. If we look at the volume of provisioning set aside since 2007, taking into account what's included in this Royal Legislative Decree, we've got provisions of 15% of Spanish GDP. As you can see, after the provisions under this Royal Decree we'll be able to absorb drops in prices in land, in projects under construction and in finished housing units.

And then fourthly, it's really vital now to start growing, and there, we need structural reforms. Lately, the best loan reform we've seen in the last few months has been that of the Labour sector. In our research department, they have estimates about what that will mean for the economy. And we think in the next four years, there could be 4 percentage points of growth added to the economy because of this reform. And Spain will have a different kind of employment market, which will be one of the most flexible in all of Europe.

But there are also other elements that should boost the capacity for growth in Spain. For example, the export sector, which has meant that the current account deficit has been brought down 64% in three years, whilst at the same time we've maintained the export levels as a share of total economy, as opposed to the U.S., where it's dropped. Productivity per capita has gone up 2% on average in the last three years, which would only be 0.2% in the euro area. So we have to continue with more reforms showing the kind of determination that we've seen over the last few months so that we can get a real capacity to grow here in Spain.

To sum up, we can say that there's no country in Europe at the moment that is carrying out as many reforms that are as deep as what we're seeing in Spain. But we have to continue with this kind of determination to push through further reforms in Spain. However, we have to have time as well in order to see the results of the reforms. But Spain isn't the only geographical area in this group in this complex situation in Europe. We might conclude that the earnings we're presenting the group this quarter because of the very recurrent nature of the revenues we get in all the geographical areas would lead us to think that we've had an excellent quarter in the first quarter of 2012.

There are three highlights that I think reflect our performance this quarter; first of all, the growth of recurring revenues in nearly all the geographical areas, and they are growing faster than expenses despite the large investments we've been putting into growth over the last few years. Net attributable profit is over €1 billion. And after having normalized the level of net trading income, we've got more provisions than we had last year. And another thing is that we've managed to comply with that 9% core capital requirement of EBA early and we've also kept up our capital buffer that is required.

So this is what's happening in all the different regions. And you can see starting with the net interest income, we've got growth of over 13%. And moreover, there's a tendency for the growth to speed up over the different quarters, even in Spain, where we see that we've got a stable growth, although quite low, at least the net interest income is going up, with careful pricing policy. In the U.S.A., it's gone down because we've changed the mix from the balance sheet both on the asset side and the liability side. And we also absorbed the impact of regulatory changes in the U.S. during 2011.

In Mexico, the growth is significantly faster than that of lending. In South America, we've got nearly 30% growth, very buoyant activity. It's the driving force of growth in the group. And then in Turkey and China or what we call Eurasia, we're seeing sound growth of our net interest income. So I'd say that the news there is positive and that trickles down into gross income.

And there I want to give you a breakdown of the most volatile parts, which are net trading income and dividends. But the underlying revenues, what we could call recurring revenues, are growing at the same rate or a very similar rate to net interest income at 12.6% a year. We've got a level of net trading income that we consider to be much more normal than what we reported in the same quarter of last year, where the positive impacts like the devaluation in Venezuela or the divestment of portfolio in the U.S., Mexico, or Spain, have meant that we reached a very extraordinary high level.

And then in costs, in expenditure there, we're seeing a growth which is below that of recurring revenues, and they're growing in the countries where we are growing most. And in the emerging countries, expenses have been growing less than the growth that we've reported in revenues. But if we include everything, the cost-to-income ratio still shows excellent performance, and we are leaders in the sector in that percentage ratio in this first quarter of 2012. So, net operating income, aggregating the costs and the recurring revenues, gives us a growth or is showing a growth of – after costs of nearly 16% in the first quarter.

And provisioning, well, there are a few things I want to say here. The level of provisioning for loan loss and real estate provisions is similar to what we've had in 2010 and 2011. And in this quarter, in particular, compared against the first quarter of last year, we're provisioning about €200 million more than in the first quarter of the previous year. And that's mainly here in Spain, where we're seeing the highest level of provisioning, which is offset by the drops that we're seeing elsewhere in the world.

Looking at the parameter under the new Royal Decree, according to the valuations of our assets, we've got provisions of €174 million. And at the same time, we are keeping the same level of generic provisioning that we had at the end of 2011. All of that means that our net attributable profit is slightly over €1 billion and well distributed over the different geographical areas, with Mexico and South America making contributions of 30% and 26%, and Spain bringing in 16%.

And if we look at the distribution between the developed and the emerging economies, 72% is coming from emerging economies and 28% from the developed economies. So, that means that we have net interest income growing. And we're seeing normalization of net trading income, which means lower revenues in net trading income, with the absorption of another €200 million; more provisioning, which means that we have dropped about €600 million, which is absorbed when we come down to the after-tax net income.

And if we look at the risk indicators, they're very stable in the group. We're seeing stable NPAs, stable coverage ratios. Over the last eight quarters, we've had this level of stability. And you can see that, that is for the group as a whole. And our ability to generate capital, I already said that we've got that 9% core capital ratio that was established by the EBA. And we've got our buffer of €2.3 billion, which is another 70 basis points which we could add to our capital. This is in an environment in which we still maintain our payout policy with two cash dividends and we have managed to avoid having to sell off any strategic assets in order to maintain our capital ratios.

Looking at core capital under Basel 2.5 standards, we've got 10.7% at the end of the quarter. And what's most relevant is that we've generated 30 basis points of capital organically. Finally, liquidity. In liquidity, as you know, we've got a very solid position. As you know, we've taken advantage of the two European Central Bank auctions and we've used the liquidity of that in order to improve the liquidity of the group, covering all the debt redemptions for 2012 and 2013 already, and we've got an ample amount of collateral available to use for discounts from the European Central Bank. And we continue to be very proactive in the management of our liquidity levels, with some €4 billion less in the credit gap over this quarter, with senior debt issues made for €2 billion in the first quarter. In the balance sheet, we've got powerful liquidity buffers.

Okay. So, let's move on to the business units, starting in Spain, as always. There are two keys to Spain here. The weak business levels, this has happened over the last couple of quarters. We've seen it in the first quarter, too. And this is a consequence of the delevering that we're seeing in general, both in household and also in companies, as I mentioned at the beginning. So, there's lots of price management here, which is improving our customer spreads, basically because of the better prices of the new assets that are taken on, both in household mortgages and in companies. As we can see in the graphs here, this has been going down over the last four quarters.

Despite the lower business levels, over the last 12 months, we have managed to gain market share both on the lending side and on the deposit side. And this, of course, means that we can confirm that we've bottomed out on the net interest income, with a slight pickup in Spain, as we can see here; this together with the performance in fees in the first quarter of this year. The next major concept is cost management in Spain. Since the crisis started, we've been saying that we're seeing reductions in costs. And this quarter, once again, we've got a 1.6% fall in costs, and this leads us to a recurring operating income of 9.1% year-on-year.

Provisioning, once again, there is a stable – that we're just as stable as we're seeing throughout their growth. They're hardly changing quarter on quarter, and the NPA ratios and the coverage ratios are very similar to the levels we've seen any recent quarters. And this leads us to the income statement, with a contribution of €227 million for the group, and as I said before, with the strong resilience that we've seen, especially in the net interest income. But in any event, one important factor here, in Spain, and despite the complex environment, is that we have almost €1 billion in operating income. That means that we can address any kind of significant provisionings that we have to do in coming quarters.

Moving on to Eurasia now, and there are two key players here, and that is reinvestment in Turkey, and the other is the investment that we've made in CITIC in China. When we talk about Turkey, we're talking about the best, the most profitable banks with the highest profits in Turkey. This is a bank that's – in 2011, has generated a gross income of over €3.8 billion and attributable profits of over €1.4 billion, and the investment in bank in China, which is the seventh largest bank in China and which is growing very fast and is offering nearly €9.5 billion in gross income and attributable profits of nearly €4 billion in 2011.

And apart from the fact that the wholesale franchise, which is based on the customers, which is going to show resilient revenues in coming quarters, too. So, basically, the numbers Turkey has started to contribute in the gross income, over €2 billion, and Europe, the rest of Europe is €368 million. So, from the point of view of the gross income from Asia comes basically from the revenues from CITIC, which is over €160 million. So, this region shows a contribution to the revenues from each of these areas that is very well balanced, which enables us to generate the resilience that we're looking for.

So, attributable profits of almost €300 million with good growth figures all the way through from the top to the bottom line. Mexico now, where the market is very dynamic, especially in lending, especially in retail for consumption, finance, PMAs, we're growing at 6.6%. But the retail are growing by 13% and customer funds have increased by over 10.4%, and this has improved the quality of the mix of our resources on the balance sheet in favor of the cheaper deposits. And this means that we can, once again, improve the customer spread to 11.5%.

And all of this has enabled us quarter after quarter to improve the growth in the net interest income at the close of this first quarter, it's 9.4% growth here, which as you can see, is higher than the average growth for the whole portfolio. And it also means that the recurring gross income is growing in line with the net interest income of around 9%. And if we included the volatile effect of net trading income because of the sale of assets that I pointed out at the beginning of the presentation, then the gross income would show a growth of around 5%.

The important factors here, after strong investments in technologies and expansion – organic expansions of branches, et cetera, what we're seeing in Mexico is that the share that we have in net income – in operating income is growing year after year and we're close to 38% at the end of 2011. If we look at risk indicators, once again, there's stability here, both in the NPAs and the risk premium has gone up by a couple of tenths. But once again, the coverage ratios are still very high.

The income statement shows a net attributable profit of around €430 million. If we take out the effect of the net trading income, this would be closer to 14%, which is the underlying speed of the growth in these incomes. And if we look at the resilient revenues, it would be closer to 9%. And we're starting to see how expenses are starting to grow at a similar rate to revenues.

South America. We continued to see strong business, both in lending and in deposits, that is growing of around 25% on both sides of the balance sheet, which means that with an improvement in customer spreads, it means we can once again present growth in the net interest income of around 30%. This is down 18.7% if we take out the fall in the contribution from the net trading income in this quarter, in comparison with the impact of the devaluation in this quarter in Venezuela.

So, we're talking about growth in this sector that's very similar to the net interest income and the operating income, given that the expenses are growing at the rate of inflation despite the measures that we've taken both at the investments we're making in technology and opening new branches and alternative networks. What we're seeing is that the operating income is growing by 22%, with expenses that are growing far lower than the recurring revenues. And this means that cost-of-income ratio has improved substantially year-on-year.

And the risk quality are the best in the group, both in the NPA ratio, the best coverage rates and the risk premium, which remains stable throughout – in the course of the last few quarters. So, this gives us a net attributable profit from South America of €370 million, which is 27% growth. And once again, I would say it is growing on all the different lines of the balance sheet. And once again, it's absorbing the effect of the Venezuelan devaluation that we saw in the first quarter of last year.

The United States now. We're continuing to see how things are transforming there and how the mix is changing both on the asset and the liability side in the United States, thanks to the new business that's being signed up in the United States every month, we're seeing a sustained new production of over $1 billion. In March, we've seen peaks of $1.8 billion. We're continuing to generate deleverage in commercial real estate. And if we take the overall picture in the United States, we're starting to see growth of 2% in lending for the first quarter in a long time.

And the important thing here is that performance of local businesses, the ones that we can locate in BBVA Compass which are growing at 7% year-on-year and as I said from the point of view on the liability side, we've improved the structure in favor of term site deposits, which are cheaper, which means that, overall, we can show a net interest income for local business and bearing in mind the effect of the markets, which are very, very flat, so we're showing year-on-year growth of 5.9%.

But there's also a positive trend if we look at the quarterly averages from last year. Expenses are following along the same lines. They're well under control, with a drop of 2.3%. And don't forget that we are currently absorbing the effects of regulations and the major investments that we're making in the new platform that we're developing in the United States.

Loan loss provisions, this has fallen by 66%. The risk premium is 0.3%. Net negative entries are negative, which means successive falls in the NPA. And despite the fact that the 66% drop in NPAs, we can see increases in the coverage rate up to 65%. So the net attributable profit is €750 million, which is 16% increase. But if we take out the net trading income effect and the fact that we've absorbed the impact of the new regulations that have been rolled out in the United States, the growth will be in higher in any event, if we take out the wholesale business. If we talk about the benefit of the local businesses, we're talking about growth of around 25%.

Corporate and investment banking, the resilience of their earnings once again is the fruit of the distribution between the different geographies in the group, which means that we're generating revenues in a far more balanced manner and a far more resilient manner. And moreover, this is based on a balance and a diversification in each of the different business units. This can be clearly seen if we look at the revenues that come from this area, and then we can see that over 90% comes with this from trading and that the efficiency levels are the lowest in the industry.

And if we look at the quality of the revenues that – from net interest income, we can see that the quality is very high and it's very resilient and apart from being compatible with a very low-risk premium, especially from the point – from a comparative point of view. And this gives us the income statement, which means that we can add an attributable profit of around €280 million.

So, just to round off and in summary, the first key is resilient growth, highly diversified growth and resilient revenues in all geographies, growth that is above costs. The second concept is attributable profit of over €1 billion after absorbing falls in earnings because of the net trading income and provisionings of €600 million. And the third important fact is that we've met the capital requirement of the EBA. We've reached our 9% well ahead of time and we're maintaining our own sovereign buffer.
Thank you very much. We can now move on to the questions.
Thank you very much, Ángel. As usual, we're going to divide the questions into blocks which will give us time to answer, particularly all the questions they're presenting.

So, let's start with the questions about the macro environment. David Vaamonde from Fidentiis is asking about our best forecasts for the performance of restructuring the financial sector as of now, and he's referring more specifically to the funding, what is the deposit guarantee fund, the FROP (30:09) going to do with regard to the upcoming loans – auction, sorry, of the Banco Valencia, the new savings bank, the Caça Catalana, and are there any other additional operations in the sector?

Well, from the information that's available to everyone, Banco de Valencia is already up for auction. And very soon, Catalunya Caça will go through the same process. And in a few months, we can expect we'll have the merged Galician Caças as well up for auction. So, that's on the basis of public information. All of these cases have to be dealt with before summer. And from the information we have, it seems that the deposit guarantee fund will cover what is needed.

So far, we haven't heard of any other transactions or what other kind of transactions could take place, or how they'd be dealt with. So, what's most important now is first of all, from the 15th of April, according to what the Bank of Spain has said, the plan has been handed in by all the different Caças in order to comply with the latest regulations in the industry.

Secondly, we know therefore what the business plans are in order to do the provisioning that they require. And we will then have a more consolidated financial industry here in a matter of months. And we're talking about the months here which are affordable for the Spanish economy as a whole. Therefore, I'd say that from now to August, we should have a much clearer idea of what's happening in terms of the rolling out and the enforcement of the new regulations and the business plans of the Caças.

And then the other block, liquidity, we've got five or six questions about the subject which I'll sum up. Francisco Riquel from N+1 asks about whether we could give an update on the exposure to public debt here in Spain that the bank has, what kind of portfolios we have, what term, what's happened over the quarter and how much has been funded with LTRO?

And then, Matteo Ramenghi from UBS asks about the use of the LTRO, and if we should reckon that this will be €10 billion of long-term refinancing operations and how much has been drawn down in Spanish government bonds in the trading book and in the available for sale and in the redemptions?
Britta Schmidt from Autonomous asked about the €10 billion increase in available for sale quarter-on-quarter, and asks if this is the carried rate?
David Vaamonde from Fidentiis asks how much the ALCO portfolio is now, what's its composition and what's it contributing to net interest income?
And from Keith here (33:34), we have a question about the LTRO, and how much is deposited in the European Central Bank? And how we are expecting to use these funds in the future?

And Benjie Creelan from Macquarie asks whether we can give some color on how the European Central Bank funds are being used and what our exposure is to Spanish government bonds? Basically, the same questions from six different analysts.

Okay. We can give a full review over this. Basically, as I said in the presentation and then Manolo give us more details. But basically, what I was saying, we've used this money to improve the group's financing structure, both in the short term and long term redemptions or maturities, so there's less short-term funding, and less exposure in the long-term and long-term, I'm talking about market issues. So, this is the basic use, irrespective of the fact that there's about 15%, I think, that we've used for investing in ALCO portfolios outside of the perimeter of the Spanish debt. Manolo, maybe you can give us some color on this.

There are a lot of questions that have been asked here, but basically, there are three or four questions that I will try to address. As you will probably remember, we've always been highly transparent with the sums that we've taken in the three-year auctions from the European Central Bank. In December, it was €11 billion and the second one, we took a very similar amount, which answers Benjie's question on how much we're taking from the second auction, and this is reflected in the income statement if you compare the first quarter with the second quarter.

So, the total requests for the three-year lending or funding has been less than 5% of our total assets. The reason behind of all this, in a cautious scenario, to cover all the wholesale maturities of mid- and long-term debt that we have in 2012 and 2013 in the euro account which, as you know, is the only account that is slightly dependent on the wholesale market.

At the same time, we're establishing a liquidity buffer in line with our policy of conservative prudence of the policy in a form of managing liquidity, and finally, to improve the euro balance liquidity structure by lengthening the maturities of this wholesale funding.

And this takes us onto the next point, and that is how we've used this money that we've got in the two auctions. As Ángel has just explained, about two-thirds of the money that we've been lent from the European Central Bank has been used to replace short-term collateralized – instead of the short-term collateral funding, we replaced this with an ECB funding. And what we've done is we've replaced covered bonds or the need-to-recover – maturities recover bond, and we've covered this with the money we've taken from the ECB.

And another 15% of the other third, so about a half of the remaining third is a liquidity buffer which has been placed in the European Central Bank. And this also answered the questions on our deposits with the ECB. And another 15% and, i.e., the other half of the final third has been used in part to increase our ALCO portfolio during this – the stability management portfolio, also on the euro balance.

In other geographies, although this has nothing to do with the auctions, but the important thing, as Ángel says, is that in this quarter, we have not increased our exposure to sovereign bonds to what could be called peripheral countries. In fact, we haven't increased our exposure to Spain. We've reduced our exposure to some other countries. And the purchase that we've made for the ALCO portfolio, and here, I'm talking about approximately, on the euro account, about €6 billion in the course of this quarter. And this has been concentrated on sovereign bonds from multilateral agencies or core European countries. And part of the money is being used to buy covered bonds or non-Spanish covered bonds and senior debt from banks. So, these €6 billion are distributed on assets of this kind, and this is the increase in the ALCO portfolio.

The average maturity of all the purchases that were taken out his quarter is approximately three years and part of the reduction of the exposure to peripheral countries were of longer-term bonds. The contribution that the ALCO portfolio made on its side, in the first quarter of 2011, the ALCO portfolio amounted to €30.4 billion and the euro balance, with a contribution of €165 million in the quarter, with average maturities of three years. December 2011 figures for this portfolio, the portfolio in full, because we reduced our exposure at the beginning of the year, and also, we did this in 2011, so €26.7 billion, with a contribution to the income statement of €108 million.

And in the first quarter of 2012, this portfolio once again has gone up to €32 billion, with the extra €6 billion that we took out, with a contribution to the income of €165 million. And the effect of the increase in the volume of that portfolio has been reduced and the most important factor is the improve in the ALCO margin has been the drop in short-term rates.

So in short, I think all of this answers your questions. As I said, the important thing is is that our exposure to Spanish sovereign debt has increased slightly on the trailing portfolio, not in the ALCO portfolio. We're talking about a different total exposure, including lending exposure of €700 million. There was a reduction in other peripheral markets of €700 million, too. So the increase of the €6 billion that I mentioned as a consequence of exposure to other core European countries, banks and multinational agencies.

One thing I'd like to add here is the effect of this auctions, the effect that they've had on our rivals – on our competition and the bank sector here in Spain, because it's reduced the pressure that we've been under for retail deposits. This is – in the presentation, I showed you a slide where we showed that over the last few quarters, the cost of term deposits have reduced and this is possibly one of the tremendously positive consequences of these auctions.

One thing I've just realized, there are two details in the questions that I haven't addressed. The figure that you can see in the increase of the available for sale is €9 billion, so it's €6 billion in the euro balance and €3 billion comes from other group balances where we've increased the portfolio in the current environment in the United States, Mexico and other areas.

I'd also like to point out that another part of the question, if we're only talking about the impact of the ECB three-year auctions on the income, this has been a neutral this quarter, because the improve in the margin, because the increase in the volume of the portfolio has been offset by the negative effect on the margin by substituting short-term funding, which is much cheaper, which is – we've replaced this with funding from the European Central Bank. So the opportunity cost of keeping our deposit in the European Central Bank or taking their funding at 1% is limited use just to adjust our liquidity positions. We don't take money from the ECB to buy things with, per se.

Okay, the next block with lending quality. Matteo Ramenghi from UBS asks about what is the NPA ratio for individual mortgages in Spain and the SME segment, and what are the prospects for the next few quarters? Carlos Berastain from Deutsche Bank asked the same question. Maybe we could give a bit more color in the quarterly performance and prospects of NPAs in Spain by segment?

McQueen (43:15) from Nomura asks about NPAs by segments and the outlook for 2012. David Vaamonde from Fidentiis, his question addresses is how we are going to face Royal Decree 2-12 in the next few quarters and maintain our EBA core capital at 9% because provisions are going to be greater in the second half of 2012. And Antonio Ramirez from Keefe asked whether in this quarter we've sold any charge-off portfolios, and to what extent, if we have the kind of assets, and at what prices are we getting for these assets?

First of all, the NPA ratio. In Spain, what we're seeing is a stabilization in the NPA ratios across the board, with one exception, which is in the business world, where we're seeing increases quarter-on-quarter, which we've seen over the last four, five quarters. Very quickly, if we go to the end of 2009, when we brought forward some provisioning, we can say that we anticipated provisions for the next six quarters, more or less. And after that, what we've been seeing is impairment, above all, in the companies sector.

This kind of impairment, what kind of impact would it have? Well, we think that it's quite affordable. It could be dealt with. We're talking about a portfolio of about €42 million. And in the presentation, I said that this is the portfolio that sees greatest deleveraging. A year ago, it would have been €48 billion. So, definitely there's a lot of deleveraging going on. This portfolio, the €41 million, has an NPA ratio of 9.8%. That's an impairment of about 60 basis points in the quarter. And we can expect to see a similar kind of impairment over the next few quarters.

And that's where we're seeing the largest figure for net additions compared to other products or segments where, in fact, we are seeing slight drops. So we can see the other sectors are offsetting this one and so NPAs are stabilizing in Spain as a whole.

If we try to analyze all of this, we can see that the NPA ratio can expect an impairment over the year of about 2%. So more or less the impact of the first quarter will be extended to the other quarters of the year. So we're talking about net additions of about €700 million, €800 million for the year as a whole, with that €11.3 billion figure that we gave for the year end. So, 30%, 40%.

And really, Manolo, we're not expecting any additional impairments elsewhere. In fact, we're looking at individual accounts and we're seeing a slight drop in NPAs there, which is what we think will offset the worst performance of the companies portfolio.

So the other question – well, that's clear, isn't it? We've talked about the provisioning under the new Royal Decree. And in the presentation, I said we've set aside €175 million. It's not a matter of anticipating or not anticipating. It's just that according to internationally accepted standards that we're subject to because our stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, so we have to comply with international standards and the IFRS standards. To give you the figures, we're talking about funding requirements or provisioning requirements. We're not expecting to make any special capital issues to be able to use those issues for the provisioning. In the first quarter and in the next few quarters, we'll see it again. And so we're expecting, say, 9% by the end of the year without even touching the sovereign buffer that we have of €2.3 billion and without selling any strategic assets, just organically generating capital and using the internal models, which we've hardly used at all so far, we have the target of reaching that 9% figure by the end of the year.
And then the sales, Manolo?

Well, in sales, over the quarter there has been no sale of any special or package or anything. We're just doing retail sales, where we've sold over 1,000 units over the quarter. And we're seeing the pace picking up compared to last year. But at the moment, we haven't got any transaction to package NPAs or foreclosed assets or charge-offs, so we're not doing that kind of securitization, but we think that there is interest in the market in getting involved in these kinds of transactions. We can't guarantee that we'll come to any agreement at the moment though, because the most important issue for the group at the moment is to conserve its medium-term values that it has in these portfolios. And, as Manolo said, the sale of these kinds of packages doesn't generate any tendencies in the retail business.

More questions about provisioning have been answered, but Britta Schmidt from Autonomous and Jaime Becerril from JPMorgan and Antonio Ramirez from Keefe, Daragh Quinn from Nomura and Chandra-Rajan from Barclays and Morgan Stanley asked about what the COO was talking about. Okay. There are three further questions with regard to do with creditworthiness or asset quality, and our forecast for 2012 with regard to asset quality and these are made by Fabio Mastrachem (55:38) and Rohith Chandra from Barclays and Juan Pablo Lopez Cobo from Computer and Investments (55:42) concerning the following: NPA continues to rise significantly in Spain, and the question is how can we justify the relatively flat performance of BBVA? I think you've answered that very clearly. But at the moment, I'd say that it used to be more difficult to understand what was happening. But now there's more transparency about the exposure to real estate and developers. Some impairment on performing loans, although only marginal in real estate, but in our case, the exposure was substantially lower in absolute and relative terms compared to the figures for our peer group as a whole here in Spain. And in terms of the quality of our homeowner mortgages there are important factors to take into account, like how many mortgages are given to people in the workforce, that's about 25% who are perfectly able to pay their mortgage loans. So we have excellent asset quality. But we are aware that there has been impairment of this portfolio over the crisis, although we think that this probably bottomed out.

And then the issue with the SMEs, we've reported on this all the time. But the non-performing assets have gone up €120 million in terms of net additions over the quarter, and that's what we're talking about. And this is concentrated in the SME sector, above all. And I think we've been quite clear and transparent about that. Thank you.

Okay, capital and dividends, I have three questions here. Stanislas de Neuville from BNP Paribas, and he asks if we can confirm that we are committed to maintaining our dividend of $0.42 per share, including the two scrip dividends?

On dividends, right. That's simple, $0.42. Our target is to stay at around about that level. And the same policy, we've had two in cash and two in scrip. Yes. Well, we still have a density of risk-weighted assets which is high, compared to total assets, it's over 50%. And that kind of density is very high. And then, what was the impact of Basel III? Do you want to talk about it?
No, no. You go ahead.

Okay, then, Basel III, there, our best estimates internally at the moment suggest the Basel III will give us capital ratios of over 9% until 2015, which is when we're budgeting for or forecasting for at the moment. That's the kind of time horizon we're using at the moment.

And then in terms of the phase-in, well, I don't know if you want us to go through what the regulations say, but that's what we will be doing. The deductions that don't have phase-in are software, access (1:07:58) in minorities and the expected losses and then tax deferred that aren't just for time lagging. So, there's no phase-in for that. That will be done all in one go. And then there are deductions that do have a phase-in, namely, tax deferrals because of time differences and investments in insurance companies and financial entities, taking into account that there's a deduction of these deductions established in the regulations.

And then, there are the requirements for risk-weighted assets for counterparty risk, which we will be covering by the end of this year and then, risk-weighted assets which do have a phase-in. I think we're getting into too much detail, really. It's – they are very technical details, but that's basically, we're just doing what it says in the regulations. And that 70 basis points that we've been talking about over the last few quarters? That's the figure that we're seeing, the difference between Basel 2.5 and Basel III.

Perhaps, what's most relevant here is that according to our forecast to 2015, which is the time horizon we're using, when we're talking about being comfortably over 9% on a recurrent basis in our core capital under Basel III. I think really, that's the best answer. We've got this stability. We're very comfortable that we have enough core capital to meet the requirements and be well over 9% indeed, without having to divest any strategic assets in order to deal with any of the phase-ins as they come up.

And then with respect to Mexico, I've got several questions all related to net interest income performance. Francisco Riquel from N+1 asks about net interest income in Mexico, saying it's flat. Can you give us an outlook for the next three quarters 2012?

Antonio Ramirez from Keefe wants to know what we expect to happen in Mexico. Do we expect the loan book to grow? Will income grow? And what about cost and provisions? Have the expectations we had at the beginning of the year changed at all?

Rohith Chandra from Barclays asks along the same lines, what kind of performance do we expect in net interest income in Mexico? It would seem that the outlook is weaker than was expected. What would have to happen to improve the performance of Mexico during 2012?

Ignacio Cerezo from Credit Suisse asks about the sensitivity of operating income to possible drops in interest rates. Juan Pablo López from Espirito Santo Investment and Carlos Berastain from Deutsche Bank ask about a possible sale of business in Mexico, the possibility of an IPO. And Jaime Becerril asks about that, from JPMorgan. And I think that's it. And then there's that question then about the possible IPO of business in Mexico.

Just to explain how the net interest income performance is around (1:17:12). If we look at recent quarters, the net interest income has grown in Mexico. There were 5% increases, 7%, 8%, and it's over 9% now in the first quarter of this year. So, this is the performance trend.

Second, when we look at the performance of net interest income in Mexico, we're putting together the operating income in local and the global business. In the global business, you see the behavior is pretty flat, which because of the fall in business in markets, not just in Europe, but also in the different areas of Latin America. And I would repeat, we're talking about a net interest income locally that's growing by over 13% and in the market – in the wholesale market, the growth is flat. So that's the first thing I would like to say.

Second key to this is lending that you are asking about. There are two kinds of growth that we're seeing. On the one hand, there's growth in the more retail segments, consumer finance, mortgages, and then there's the world of SMEs. Versus the deleverage that we're seeing with 30% falls basically in the developers sector, which is very similar to the effect we're seeing in Spain or what we saw before in the U.S. and the retail world, where lending is growing at rates of around 13%.

So, we've got sound and dynamic growth on the retail side and far lower growth in companies and deleverage in the development sector. The local businesses are growing their net interest income by over 13%, which offsets the flat growth of the wholesale business.

With regard to the business for the year as whole, I think lending will grow – we'll see double-digit growth between 9% and 11%, I think. And so, we're seeing more than we're seeing at the moment, very similar in retail, and I think there's a bit more business in the company side, if we take out the effect of deleveraging of the development sector.

Costs now. The objective here by the end of the year is to see – and they should be growing by no more than recurrent revenues. And next year, there should be growth – cost should be growing less than revenues.

Provisions now. Provisions for the first quarter are more or less in line with our budget and what we're budgeting for the year as a whole, so we're seeing risk premiums that are very similar to what we've seen in the first quarter. I don't think there's going to be any great change there. So, that's earnings.

The other question addresses a possible IPO. I think there are two issues here. First of all, from the point of view of capital needs, for the group as a whole, as both Manolo and myself has asked and answered in previous questions, we have no capital needs for regulatory reasons. So, for those reasons, there will be no IPO in Mexico.

Second point, there could be an alleged capital need in Mexico because of a regulatory process, whereby new hybrid vehicles are being developed, which could be considered as capital in Mexico. This would be if the Mexican authorities think that they had to cover hybrid vehicles at that time. But at the moment, our capital ratios in Mexico are over 15%, and the minimum requirement is 8% or the recommendable would be about 10%. But we're clearly well above the regulatory capital requirement, so we don't need any IPO there.

From a strategic point of view, which would be the third part of this, we're talking about the franchise where we continue to see opportunities for growth, especially organic growth, because of bringing new customers into the bank and the increased business in Mexico. So it wouldn't make any sense from a strategic point of view to deleverage there, maybe some alternative investment with similar levels of growth. But at the moment, this is not on the horizon.

We have another three or four minutes and about 10 to 12 questions to get through, so I'll try to select two or three most important things. Then in the course of the day, Investor Relations will attempt to answer all of them.

Maybe you'd like to talk about our role in Europe?
